Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Fever, cough, and difficulty breathing for 5 days.

Present Illness.Onset: Onset occurred 5 days ago at home with sudden onset of high fever. No known trigger.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Persistent dry cough, moderate difficulty breathing, fever of 38.5°C. Symptoms aggravated by exertion.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: General malaise, mild chest pain during coughing.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Patient visited a local clinic 3 days ago and was prescribed antibiotics with no improvement.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Decreased appetite, difficulty sleeping due to cough, normal urination and defecation, slight weight loss.

Past History.General Health Condition: Generally good prior to current illness.
Past History.Disease History: Hypertension for 10 years, well controlled with medication.
Past History.Immunization History: Up-to-date with vaccinations, including influenza and pneumococcal vaccine.

Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Retired teacher, no significant occupational hazards.
Personal History.Exposure History: No exposure to industrial toxins or radioactive substances.

Marital History.Children's Condition: Two children, both in good health.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Mother had diabetes, father had chronic bronchitis. No known genetic tendencies.

Systematic Examination.Chest: Dullness to percussion over right lower lobe, crackles heard on auscultation. Heart sounds normal.

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Pulmonary auscultation revealed crackles over the right lower lobe.
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Chest X-ray showed consolidation in the right lower lobe, elevated WBC count, CRP elevated.
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Based on patient's history of fever, cough, difficulty breathing, physical exam findings, and chest X-ray results.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Tuberculosis: ruled out due to lack of chronic symptoms and relevant exposure history. Lung cancer: less likely given acute presentation and lack of weight loss. Pulmonary embolism: ruled out due to absence of risk factors and sudden onset.

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: Patient presented with symptoms indicative of pneumonia. Initial treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics and supportive measures initiated.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Patient monitored daily. Fever subsided on the 2nd day, continued improvement in respiratory symptoms.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Patient reviewed on rounds. Satisfactory progress, continue current management.
Post-Admission Course Records.Handover Records: Patient handed over to night shift with stable vitals, continue current treatment.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Patient showed significant improvement, afebrile for 48 hours, respiratory symptoms resolving.
Post-Admission Course Records.Discharge Records: Patient discharged home in stable condition with oral antibiotics and follow-up in 1 week.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: 1. Broad-spectrum antibiotics IV 2. Oxygen therapy 3. Monitor vital signs every 4 hours

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: 1. Chest X-ray: Right lower lobe consolidation. 2. CBC: Elevated WBC count. 3. CRP: Elevated.
Hospitalization Record.Temperature Chart: Records indicate fever decreased progressively from 38.5°C to normal over 48 hours.
